Violation_Type: Refusal of permanent residence application under provincial nominee class
Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer committed a reviewable error in refusing the application
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 87(3)
Application_Facts: Applicant had family support and provincial endorsement but was found lacking initiative or motivation; lived in Canada as a visitor for two years without demonstrating financial self-sufficiency
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Officer's decision
Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residence under provincial nominee class
Defendant_Behavior: Officer exercised discretion to substitute assessment of economic establishment despite nomination
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged reviewable error in refusal decision
Assessment_Factor: Likelihood of economic establishment, lack of demonstrated initiative or motivation
Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 72(1); Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 87(3)
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly mentioned, but implicit in evaluation of applicantâ€™s behavior and motivation
Evidence_Used: Nomination certificate, evidence of two-year stay as visitor, lack of financial self-sufficiency during stay
Legal_Provision_Cited: s. 87(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Evidence_Assessed: Support from family, provincial endorsement, duration and nature of stay in Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturning of refusal decision through judicial review
Governing_Rule: Officer may substitute their own assessment if nomination is not a sufficient indicator of economic establishment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate financial self-sufficiency over two years in Canada
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; refusal deemed reasonable
Decisional_Body: Immigration Officer, with concurring officer; reviewed by Federal Court
Harm_Assessment: No harm established due to reasonable decision-making process
Cause_Description: Applicant's inability to demonstrate financial self-sufficiency over two years in Canada as a visitor
Evidence_Handling: Officer assessed nomination and personal circumstances, including conduct during temporary stay
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient evidence of economic initiative or self-support despite opportunity
Residency_Compliance: Complied with visitor status but failed to establish economic independence
Legal_Provision: s. 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Officer evaluated likelihood of economic establishment independently despite nomination
Decision_Rationale: Nomination not determinative; officer reasonably concluded applicant lacked motivation for economic establishment
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of documentation or proof of employment, income, or integration efforts during stay
